paragraphs.text:
%md 
#### Count number of rows in wdi_csv_text using Bash and Hive
- fs cache for all nodes is cleared before Hive operation
- fs cache for the master node is cleared before Bash operation
- The Hive operation takes longer (41s) as expected since it has to load files from different nodes into the Hive table and then perform the operation as Tez tasks through YARN
- The Bash operation takes less time (19s) as expected since it can access the files locally and perform the operation directly on the files

msg.data:
Count number of rows in wdi_csv_text using Bash and Hive

  • fs cache for all nodes is cleared before Hive operation
  • fs cache for the master node is cleared before Bash operation
  • The Hive operation takes longer (41s) as expected since it has to load files from different nodes into the Hive table and then perform the operation as Tez tasks through YARN
  • The Bash operation takes less time (19s) as expected since it can access the files locally and perform the operation directly on the files

In the wdi_gs table, we used the default SerDe with “ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS TERMINATED BY ‘,’”; therefore this assumes that every line in the file contains 6 fields, all separated by ‘,’;
however, from the result above it is clear that the 4th field of some lines (indicator names) are themselves separeated by ‘,’, which creates 7 fields for those lines; this makes the SerDe place the 2nd part of the indicator name field in the indicator code column of the table, which is not correct.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Create a new table to be stored in HDFS from the previously created wdi_opencsv_gs table, which is now correctly parsed; use the same OpenCSV SerDe
As mentioned above, the parsing problem occurs for the lines on the file whose indicator name field is itself separated by ','; the OpenCSV SerDe treats all columns to be of type String and since the problematic fields are of the form "... , ...." including the outer quotes, this SerDe takes everything inside those quotes as a single field (indicator name - see above), which the default SerDe is not able to do; this solves our parsing problem for the indicator name and indicator code columns.

paragraphs.text:
%md
wdi_csv_text performs much faster (26s) than wdi_opencsv_text (43s); this is because:
- wdi_csv_text uses Hive's default SerDe (LazySimpleSerDe); it deserializes fields lazily — only as they are accessed, which provides better performance
- wdi_opencsv_text uses OpenCSVSerDe, which does not make use of lazy deserialization

- wdi_opencsv_text uses OpenCSVSerDe, which does not make use of lazy deserialization
